Graphical abstract Efficient upgrading of lignin bio-oils into oxygen-free liquid alkane fuels is a challenging task owing to the incompatibility of the phenolic feedstock with conventional fuels and the availability of effective hydrotreating catalysts based on the current refinery infrastructure. In this work, a series of solid acid nanosheets (HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, HTaWO6) modified Pt/CNTs bifunctional catalysts were evaluated in hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin-derived compounds. The effects of types of nanosheets and the synergistic effect between metal sites and acid sites were discussed via HDO of diphenyl ether. Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst exhibited the most efficient performance for the HDO of diphenyl ether to cyclohexane (conversion: 99.7%, selectivity: 96.4%) at 200 °C, 3.0 MPa. Several lignin aromatic model compounds including phenol, anisole, 2-phenylethyl phenyl ether and guaiacol were also investigated over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst. Due to the different bond-dissociation energies of CO bond and steric hindrance effect, guaiacol and phenol are more difficult to be converted than diphenyl ether and anisole based on the yield of cyclohexane. It was found that the Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst exhibited favorable stability. These results validated that it is desirable to utilize this catalyst in the HDO of actual lignin macromolecules into hydrocarbon fuels. Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Solid acid nanosheets Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs Lignin Synergistic effect 1 Introduction Biorefinery using renewable biomass resources offer competitive advantages such as improved sustainability, stronger economic growths, and more cost competitive products over conventional petroleum refinery using fossil feedstock [1]. Lignin is a three-dimensional aromatic biopolymer produced by pulp and paper industries [2] and always left as residual waste or as low-value-added solid fuel after utilization of hemicelluloses and cellulose of biomass to produce such as bioethanol in the biorefinery processes [3]. Besides, lignin is an abundant, globally available resource that exhibits as an alternative for fossil energy with high sustainability. Nevertheless, several defects such as thermal instability, high oxygen content, and high viscosity, leading to inevitable difficulties in using lignin directly as transportation fuels [4–7]. Abundant research efforts have been devoted to transforming lignin into value-added aromatics and fuel-range hydrocarbons, including hydrodeoxygenation (HDO), esterification, catalytic cracking, etc. [6]. Among all, HDO is regarded as the most effective technology for the removal of oxygen and transformation of lignin into clean oxygen-free hydrocarbon fuels [8–11]. Therefore, it is crucial to develop highly effective catalytic systems for lignin HDO. Due to the complex structure of lignin macromolecule, lignin-derived model compounds are usually used as probe molecules. Generally, HDO of lignin-derived compounds were widely investigated over bifunctional catalysts, which couples together the metal active sites and acid sites. The metal active sites are responsible for hydrogenation of aromatic ring, and the acid sites are responsible for removing of oxygen via dehydration [8,9,12]. For example, phenol can be efficiently converted into hydrocarbons over bifunctional catalysts such as: Ni/γ-Al2O3 [9], Ni/HZSM-5 [12]. Yao et al. found that the oxygen-containing groups in lignin-derived phenolic compound such as diphenyl ether could be efficiently removed over bifunctional catalyst Ru/H-Beta [8]. Bifunctional catalyst Ru/HZSM-5 was also employed in HDO of phenolic monomers and dimeric model compounds with excellent activity and cyclohexane yield [13]. In spite of current achievements on the HDO of lignin-derived model compounds, the development of highly efficient, water-tolerant, and stable catalysts working under mild conditions is still underexplored. Niobic acid (Nb2O5·nH2O), as a potential solid Lewis acid which remains unaltered activity in the presence of water, its performance was recently examined in dehydration and HDO reaction [14–16]. Jin et al. studied the HDO of diphenyl ether over Ni/30NbAc and 67% selectivity of cyclohexane was obtained [17]. Shao et al. explored the direct lignin upgrading over Ru/Nb2O5 and an exceptional C7–C9 arene selectivity of 71 wt.% was acquired [18]. It was reported that the solid acid with proton-exchanged form of layered transition metal oxide possesses the advantages of strong acidity, adjustable surface properties, interlayered channel, and excellent selectivity for esterification reactions [19]. Recently, HTiNbO5, HNbMoO6, and HNb3O8 etc. have been applied for dehydration [20], photocatalysis [21], esterification [19], deacetalization, and hydrogenation [22]. These two-dimensional nanosheets are highly acidic due to the bridging hydroxyl groups and represent a novel type of materials containing Brønsted acid sites [23]. However, to the best of our knowledge, only a few reports have been published on two-dimensional solid acid nanosheets as novel catalytic materials for HDO of lignin and their modest activities which may due to the relatively low specific surface area [20]. In this work, we developed a series of highly efficient exfoliated nanosheets (HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, HTaWO6) modified Pt/CNTs dual-functional catalysts, which were employed in the HDO of lignin model compounds, especially in the HDO of 4-O-5 type of model compounds due to the relatively high bond energy of 4-O-5 (∼330 kJ/mol) compared with α-O-4 type (∼215 kJ/mol) and β-O-4 (∼290 kJ/mol) [24]. Combining the structure characterization and reaction results the synergistic effect of metal active site and solid acid site have been investigated. The HDO property of mixed lignin-derived model compounds over HNbWO6 modified Pt/CNTs catalyst was discussed. In addition, the stability of HDO of diphenyl ether over time on stream was investigated over Pt/HNbWO6 CNTs catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The solid acid nanosheets modified CNTs supported Pt bifunctional catalysts were prepared by a three-step method involving support functionalization, decoration with Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets, followed by impregnation with 0.5 wt.% Pt. The Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets (HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, and HTaWO6) were synthesized by proton exchange of layered LiNbWO6, LiNbMoO6, and LiTaWO6 that prepared by calcining the stoichiometric amounts of Li2CO3 and metal oxides (Nb2O5–WO3, Nb2O5–MoO3, and Ta2O5–WO3) at 800 °C for 24 h according to the literature procedures [19]. Typically, shaking 10.0 g of the lithium salt in 200 mL of HNO3 (2 mol/L) at 50 °C for 5 days, followed by exchanging the acid liquor every day. The solid was then washed with deionized water repeatedly and dried at 80 °C overnight. Exfoliation of the layered HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, and HTaWO6 to the corresponding nanosheets were performed by insertion of voluminous and hydrophilic cations to expand the interlayer spaces of the layered structures. At this stage, 25 wt.% of TBAOH (tetra (n-butylammonium) hydroxide) solution was added to 150 mL of the deionized water containing 2.0 g of the protonated compound until the pH reached 9.5–10.0, and finally the resulting solution was stirred for 7 days. Subsequently, the suspension was centrifuged and the supernatant solution which contains the dispersed nanosheets was collected, labeled as HNbWO6, HNbMoO6 and HTaWO6 nanosheets, respectively. The Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets modified CNTs were prepared by nanosheets aggregation. Firstly, CNTs (Shenzhen NTP Co. Ltd.) with a diameter of 20–40 nm and a purity > 97% were functionalized by acid mixture according to the reported literature procedures [25]. Secondly, 100 mL 1.0 mol/L HNO3 was added into the flask contained 2.0 g the oxidized CNTs and 100 mL Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets solution and then stirred at 50 °C for 6 h in order to aggregate nanosheets samples. The mixture was then filtered and washed with deionized water repeatedly followed by drying at 80 °C overnight. The dried solid was weighted and the loading was calculated (the error is <3%). Ultimately, the as-prepared nanaosheets modified CNTs supports were impregnated with 1.34 mL H2PtCl6·6H2O aqueous solution (1.0 g/100 mL), and then dried at 80 °C, calcined at 400 °C for 3 h to obtain the Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets modified Pt/CNTs catalysts. 2.2 Characterization The specific surface areas of the catalysts were measured by nitrogen physisorption using an Autosorb iQ automated gas sorption analyzer. Prior to measurements, the samples were degassed in vacuum at 200 °C for 12 h. The specific surface area was determined using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation, while the pore diameter was determined using Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. The loading of Pt was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Optima 2000 DV). For the analysis, 5.0 mg sample is dissolved in a mixture of acids (5 mL perchloric acid and 5 mL nitric acid). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the powdered samples were measured on a D/MAX-2400 diffractometer using a Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å), operated at 40 KV and 100 mA. The distribution of metal active sites and nanosheets were determined by high-angle annular detector dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HADDF-STEM) images on a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 equipped with a digitally processed STEM imaging system. Powder samples were ultrasonicated in ethanol and dispersed on holey carbon films on copper grids. Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) (Nova NanoSEM 450 from FEI Co.) with X-ray microanalysis was used to determine the mapping of the elements on the surface of the catalyst. NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) study was carried out on an automatic chemical adsorption instrument (Quantachrome ChemBET-3000) to probe the surface acid of the samples. Typically, the reduced catalysts were degassed in helium at 500 °C for 1 h, then NH3 was vaporized at 100 °C and pulsed to the reduced samples (0.1 g) until the samples were saturated. Subsequently, excessive physically adsorbed ammonia was removed by purging with helium for 40 min, the catalysts were heated to 480 °C at 10 °C/min. 2.3 Catalytic HDO reactions HDO of lignin-derived compounds were carried out in a stainless steel fixed-bed continuous flow reactor (inner diameter of 8 mm, length of 74 cm). For each run, 0.05 g catalysts diluted in 5 mL quartz was loaded in the middle of the reactor between two pillows of quartz wool and reduced under 300 °C for 2 h (H2: 40 mL/min) before HDO experiments. The liquid feedstock included 5.0 wt.% reactant in n-decane and 2.0 wt.% n-dodecane (as an internal standard for gas chromatography analysis), which were pumped into the fixed-bed reactor at different flow rates (0.05–0.60 mL/min). Once the reaction reached steady state, the products were collected at different space time (W/F) defined as the ratio between the mass of catalyst (g) and the flow rate of the substrate (g/min). Reactant and liquid products were identified by an Agilent 7890B GC (HP-5, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) with 5977 A MSD and analyzed off-line by gas chromatograph (Bruker GC 450, FID, FFAP capillary column 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm). The carbon balance was calculated in each run, and was found to be in the range of 100 ± 3%. Catalytic performance was estimated by the conversion of reactant (conv.%), selectivity toward product i (S i %), and yield of product i (Y i %) were determined according to the following equations: (1) C o n v . % = n reactant i n p u t − n reactant o u t p u t n reactant i n p u t × 100 % (2) S i % = n i n reactant i n p u t − n reactant o u t p u t × 100 % (3) Y i % = n i n reactant i n p u t × 100 % where n(reactant)input, n(reactant)output and n i depict the molar of carbon in initial input reactant, output reactant, and the product i, respectively. In order to eliminate the possible influence of reactor, the blank experiment was investigated. As expected, the conversion of diphenyl ether is basically close to zero and no products were detected in GC–MS. In addition, the HDO of mixture of lignin-derived model compounds (DPE, anisole, guaiacol, and phenol) were evaluated over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst. The products from HDO of mixture reactants in all experiments were identified and analyzed by GC–MS and GC, the main products are cyclohexane, cyclohexanol, 1,2-cyclohexanediol, cyclohexyl methyl ether, cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether, cyclohexyl phenyl ether. The following equations were used to estimate the total conversion of reactants (conv. %) and products selectivity (S i %): (4) C o n v . % = n m i x e d r e a c tan t s i n p u t − n m i x e d r e a c t a n t s o u t p u t n m i x e d r e a c tan t s i n p u t × 100 % (5) S i % = n i n m i x e d r e a c tan t s i n p u t − m i x e d r e a c tan t s o u t p u t × 100 % where n(mixed reactant)input, n(mixed reactant)output and n i depict the molar of carbon in initial input mixed reactant, output mixed reactant, and the product i, respectively. 3 Results and discussion The layered HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, and HTaWO6 is exfoliated with tetrabutyl ammonium hydroxide (TBAOH) and then mixes with CNTs by nitric acid aggregation, respectively, which are used as support for loading Pt nanoparticles. The XRD patterns of the as prepared solid acid nanosheets modified CNTs supported Pt bifunctional catalysts are presented in Fig. 1 . Specifically, the diffraction peak at 2θ = 25.6° and 43.0° belong to CNTs (002) and (100) lattice planes, and those at 2θ = 26.4°, 37.9°, and 55.2° peaks can be attributed to nanosheets (HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, and HTaWO6) (110), (200), and (220) lattice planes, respectively [23,26]. Notably, the diffraction peak at 2θ = 6.8° ((002) lattice plane, as shown in Figure S1, almost disappeared after exfoliation, which suggests that the layered compounds were entirely transformed into nanosheets structure. These results are in good agreement with that reported by Tagusagawa [23]. However, the intensity of (110) and (200) diffraction peak of Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs sample is significantly weaker than that of Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs sample, indicating that the dispersion of HNbWO6 nanosheets on CNTs are higher than that of HTaWO6 nanosheets. Additionally, the diffraction peak at 2θ = 39.8° is identified as Pt (111) lattice plane. To understand the HDO properties of the as prepared Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets modified Pt/CNTs catalysts, catalytic evaluation of HDO of diphenyl ether (DPE) was performed with various catalysts in a fixed bed reactor operating under 200 °C and 3.0 MPa H2, as shown in Fig. 2 . The products from HDO of DPE were identified and analyzed by GC-MS and GC, including cyclohexane, cyclohexanol, benzene, cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether, cyclohexyl phenyl ether, and phenol. The conversion of DPE over Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets modified Pt/CNTs catalysts is of no significant change when compared with Pt/CNTs catalyst, but the product distribution has been notably changed. The selectivity to cyclohexane over different types of nanosheets decorated catalysts was all improved. Typically, the selectivity to cyclohexane dramatically increases from 19.5% over Pt/CNTs catalyst to 96.4% over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst. For the Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs catalyst, the selectivity to cyclohexane reaches 36%. It is worth mentioning that the Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs catalyst exhibits the highest cyclohexane selectivity (98.3%). These results demonstrate that the modification of Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets may strongly promote cleavage of C-O bond. The differential abilities of breaking up of C-O ether bonds may be attributed to the fundamental difference in the number of acid sites and acid strength of Nb(Ta)-based solid acid nanosheets, which will be confirmed by NH3-TPD results. It is well known that the efficient deoxygenation of lignin model compounds can be achieved when the metal hydrogenation functionality is combined with a mineral acid/acidic support to activate oxygen-containing functional groups or the metal or vacancy to catalytic hydrogenolysis of CO bonds [9,12,27–31]. To figure out the bifunctionality of Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst, the comparison of the HDO properties of Pt/HNbWO6 and HNbWO6/CNTs has been tested and the results are shown in Fig. 2. The conversion of DPE is barely 16.0% over Pt/HNbWO6, which is far less than Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs, indicating that CNTs play a significant role in dispersing metal active sites. In addition, comparing the HDO properties of HNbWO6/CNTs and Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalysts, a conclusion can be drawn that the metal active sites are necessary for the hydrogenation of aromatic ring. Interestingly, HNbWO6/CNTs presents 5% DPE conversion, suggesting that acid sites could also promote hydrogenation. Moreover, the Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs exhibits slightly higher conversion than Pt/CNTs further validates that the acid sites near the metal sites may lead to promotion of the hydrogenation step. Therefore, the Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst couples metal active sites and acid sites to achieve the highly efficient HDO of DPE and we speculate that there might be a synergistic effect between metal species and acid sites. In summary, Pt nanoparticles are inevitably involved in the hydrogenation step, while CNTs are essential for dispersion of Pt particles through the surface defects to anchor metal sites, and the HNbWO6 solid acid nanosheets are responsible for deoxygenation process. Generally, the distribution of Pt nanoparticles acts as an important role in the absorption and activation of the substrate molecules and solid acid sites promoted the CO bonds cleavage. Since there is a synergistic effect between metal sites and acid sites in the HDO of lignin-derived compounds, we performed ICP-OES, N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms, SEM, and HADDF-STEM experiments to detect the textural properties of Pt/CNTs, Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs, Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs, and Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs catalysts. NH3-TPD experiments were also carried out to investigate the intensity of acid of these catalysts for decoding the conversion and selectivity differences. The content of Pt analyzed by ICP-OES was found to be ca. 0.4 wt.%. As summarized in Table 1 , the specific surface area of Pt/CNTs was 134 m2/g. After incorporation of different solid acid nanosheets, the specific surface area decreases as well as pore volume, suggesting that part of surface pores of CNTs were blocked by nanosheets. It should be pointed out that the specific surface area of Pt/CNTs sharply decreased by 64 m2/g after decoration with 20 wt.% HTaWO6 (70 m2/g) nanosheets, which is far less than Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs (107 m2/g) and Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs (118 m2/g). This may be due to the surface of CNTs is heavily covered by HTaWO6 nanosheets, which is in agree with the XRD results. The detailed N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of samples with BJH pore size distributions derived from the adsorption branches of the isotherms are displayed in Fig. S2. The average pore diameter basically remained unchanged after nanosheets modification. To give a good explanation of the distribution of Pt nanoparticles and nanosheets, HADDF-STEM images of the Pt/CNTs, Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs, Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs and Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs were studied and shown in Fig. 3 . Clearly, the metal active sites are uniformly dispersed on the surface of catalysts. The histograms of Pt particles distribution were depicted in Fig. S3, the average particle size is ca. 4.5 nm in each catalyst. TEM mapping images of Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs were also employed to investigate the distribution of the elements of Pt, Nb, W, C and O, depicted in Fig. 3(e). It is anticipated that the large flaky bright spots attach on CNTs close to the metal sites are attributed to solid acid nanosheets, as shown in the dotted box of Fig. 3. This structure may be beneficial in promoting the synergistic effect of metal sites and acid sites. Moreover, SEM images of Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs and the corresponding elemental mapping analysis of the catalysts were also employed, as shown in Fig. S4. The elemental mapping analysis gives a direct vision of the distribution of each element. As expected, the Pt nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed on the surface of the catalyst, as well as Nb and W elements. Fig. 4 presents the NH3-TPD profiles of the Pt/CNTs, Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs, Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs, and Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs catalysts. It was reported that the area of the peaks representing the concentration of acid sites on the catalysts and the strength of the acid sites of the catalysts were related to the temperature of the NH3 desorption [32], typically: weak acid sites (<300 °C), medium acid sites (between 300 °C and 500 °C), and strong acid sites (>500 °C) [33]. Based on this classification, a broad NH3-desorption peak centered at 210 °C is identified as the weak acid sites. Additionally, there are mainly two NH3-desorprtion peaks centered at 360 °C (Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs) and 440 °C (Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs) identified as the medium acid sites. The number of weak acid sites, medium acid sites, and total acid sites were calculated and listed in Table 1. Clearly, only Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs and Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalysts exhibit medium acid sites, and Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs catalyst exhibits the highest density of acid sites (13.230 × 10−3 mmol/gcatalyst). Although both Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs and Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs catalysts have similar amount of total acid sites, the amount of the medium acid sites of Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs is slightly more than Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs. The acid strength is strongly dependent on strong Brønsted acid sites attributed to bridged OH groups formed only on nanosheets. It should be pointed out that the Pt/CNTs shows a broad desorption peak, indicating that the acid sites have been generated on CNTs surface after acid treatment. Similar phenomenon was also observed by Deng [34] and Huang [35]. Combined with NH3-TPD results we can conclude that the strong acid sites are more effective in cleaving of CO ether bond than weak acid sites even though Pt/HNbMoO6/CNTs have the largest amount of acid sites. Despite the Pt/HTaWO6/CNTs catalyst has medium acid sites and displays the best deoxygenation property, the relatively lower hydrogenation ability limits its HDO performance compared with Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs (Fig. 2). Based on the above consideration, Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs was selected and used to further elucidate the performance of HDO of DPE in the following study. The products distribution and selectivity of products as a function of W/F over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs were investigated, as depicted in Fig. 5 a and b. Obviously, the main products were cyclohexane, cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether and cyclohexyl phenyl ether. The relative concentration and selectivity of cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether increases first and then decreases with increasing W/F, which indicated that cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether is an intermediate product. Additionally, the relative concentration of cyclohexyl phenyl ether is the highest at low W/F (<3 gcatal. min/gDPE) and the selectivity of cyclohexyl phenyl ether gradually declines with increasing W/F. These results indicate that the single ring hydrogenation product cyclohexyl phenyl ether is the primary product of HDO of DPE and then it goes through the further hydrogenation to form cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether. The relative concentration and selectivity of cyclohexane continuously increases with increasing W/F, suggested that the cyclohexane is final product. Hence, we proposed that the specific reaction processes are composed of stepwise metal-catalyzed hydrogenation, acid-catalyzed hydrogenolysis and dehydration. The HDO of DPE is proposed to occur through HYD reaction pathway. The first step involves hydrogenation of the single aromatic leading to cyclohexyl phenyl ether and then complete hydrogenation to cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether. This result reveals that the first step of transformation of DPE is catalyzed by Pt metal active sites. C-O bond of cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether can be sequentially cleaved and turned cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether into cyclohexanol and cyclohexane, then cyclohexanol can be further dehydrated under the promotion of acid sites to produce cyclohexene and subsequently hydrogenated rapidly to form cyclohexane. However, cyclohexene was not identified because of it is very easy to react with hydrogen to produce cyclohexane. Negligible of benzene and phenol were found at low W/F signifying that little portions of DPE was transformed through hydrogenolysis reaction. The benzene and phenol may be further hydrogenated to form cyclohexane and cyclohexanol. The proposed reaction pathway is shown in Scheme 1 . Reaction temperature has a pronounced effect on conversion and product selectivity. Therefore, the effects of reaction temperature on upgrading of DPE were examined over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst under the condition of 3.0 MPa and W/F = 15.2 gcatal. min/gDPE, as shown in Fig. 5c. With increasing reaction temperature from 160 °C to 200 °C, the conversion of DPE and the selectivity of cyclohexane change dramatically. Further extending the temperature to 220 °C, the DPE completely converted (99.9%), and the selectivity of cyclohexane reaches 99.4%. The oxygenated products cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether is the main product at low temperature and the yield decreases successively with increasing temperature. The influence of hydrogen pressure on the conversion efficiency was also explored. Fig. 5d exhibits the products selectivity and DPE conversion under hydrogen pressure in the range of 0.5–3.0 MPa at 200 °C. It is found that the H2 pressure is another important parameter. The conversion of DPE gradually increases from 63.9% to 98.8% with the pressure increasing from 0.5 to 3.0 MPa. Therein to, the selectivity of deoxygenation product cyclohexane steadily grows from 30.1% to 89.2%. Cyclohexyl cyclohexyl ether is also the main oxygenated compounds product at low pressure and then decreases with increasing hydrogen pressure. These results clearly suggest that high H2 pressure guarantees the route of hydrogenation and lead to increasing yield of the hydrogenation products cyclohexane, similar results were also reported by Goncalves [36]. To demonstrate the versatility of this HDO approach, HDO reactions of several other lignin-derived model compounds including phenol, anisole, 2-phenylethyl phenyl ether (denoted as 2-PPE) and guaiacol were carried out for the production of oxygen-free cyclohexane over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs and the results are listed in Table 2 . Extensive research efforts have been devoted to bifunctional catalysts HDO of lignin model compounds, in which metal-catalyzed hydrogenation of aromatic ring is faster than the acid-catalyzed removal of the oxygen-containing groups [8,12]. Analogously, in this work, DPE, phenol, anisole, 2-PPE and guaiacol are hydrogenated first and then deoxygenated. Apart from phenol and guaiacol, DPE (99.9%), 2-PPE and anisole (96.2%) are basically quantitatively converted at 200 °C. According to previous report, the bond-dissociation energies (BDEs) of each type of CO bond follow an order of Ph–OH (106.8 kcal/mol) > Ph–OMe (91.5 kcal/mol) > Ph–O–Me (52.2 kcal/mol) [37]. Hence, the poor activity of HDO of phenol may be attributed to the highest BDEs of CO bond in phenol. In addition, the position of functional groups due to the steric hindrance could have a strong influence on the degree of HDO [38]. Based on the above consideration, the lowest activity of HDO of guaiacol could be attributed to the steric hindrance influence of the ortho-substituted sp3 methoxy group making the aromatic ring more difficult to be hydrogenated compared to phenol [39], as can be compared with similar results reported by Song et al. [12]. It is well known that high temperature will prominently in favor of CO bond breaking, whereupon, HDO of phenol, anisole, and guaiacol at 300 °C was also tested, as shown in Table 2. As expected, the conversion of phenol and anisole reach 100% with high selectivity of cyclohexane, while the conversion of guaiacol increases from 16.7% to 36.6%, and the selectivity of cyclohexane increased from 40.4% to 73.2% concurrently. These results indicate that high reaction temperature significantly promote the cleavage of CO bonds and subsequently improve the catalytic activity. Moreover, owing to the highest BDEs of C(sp2) OH scission, the main products of HDO of guaiacol are cyclohexane and cyclohexanol. Additionally, the yield of alkane is 100% in HDO of β-O-4 model compound 2-PPE, while the yield of alkane is 96.1% in HDO of 4-O-5 model compound diphenyl ether. This result indicates that the cleavage of C-O ether bond in β-O-4 linkage model compound may more easy than C-O ether bond in 4-O-5 linkage model compound. Besides, the HDO of mixture of lignin-derived model compounds were also evaluated over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst, and the results are presented in Table 2. Clearly, the conversion of mixture A (82.0%) is lower than the conversion of single substrate DPE (99.7%) and anisole (96.2%), as seen in Table 2. The conversion of mixture B and mixture C is increased, especially for mixture B, when compare to the single aromatic model compound phenol and guaiacol. This can be attributed to the reduction of the concentration of the refractory reactants which is helpful for facilitating conversion of the mixed substrates. In addition, the selectivity of cyclohexane dramatically increased after half of anisole was replaced by DPE, which indicates that it is easier for DPE to be deoxygenated than anisole. This is mainly because of the BDEs of C(sp2)–OMe (91.5 kcal/mol) is much higher than the BDEs of CO bond in DPE (78.9 kcal/mol) [12,24]. Notably, the conversion of substrate mixture C significantly decreases from 88.0% to 18.8% after guaiacol is added. We speculate that this might be because of the active sites were occupied by guaiacol, which could be hard to be converted under this mild condition (200 °C, 3.0 MPa) due to the high BDEs of CO bond and the steric hindrance effect. To confirm this assumption, the reaction temperature was extended to 300 °C. As a result, the conversion is increase to 38.9% at 300 °C. It is worth mentioning that the conversion of guaiacol reaches 64.5% under this conditions, which is higher than other single substrates’ in this mixed system reaction (not shown in this paper). These results imply that the guaiacol is preferentially adsorbs at the active sites and subsequently hinders the conversion of other single substrates, and ultimately resulting in a low conversion of mixture C. Summarizing the above discussion, it could be inferred that obvious interactions among components existed in the reaction system could have a negative impact on the HDO reaction, such as competitive adsorption, while the details of this phenomenon is not discussed here. More importantly, the selectivity of cyclohexane exceeds 70% in each HDO of mixed substrate reaction, which means that the Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs is a favorable catalyst to produce alkane fuel. However, further application of this catalyst into the HDO of direct actual lignin reaction requires a demanding conditions, such as high reaction temperature and high metal loading. Catalyst stability is of great importance to many industrial processes. To investigate our system, the conversion of DPE and products selectivity over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst as a function of time on stream (TOS) were performed at 200 °C, 3.0 MPa and the results, as shown in Fig. 6 . Evidently, the catalyst performance basically remains unchanged within the first 18 h at W/F = 27.3 gcatal. min/gDPE. In order to further illustrate the catalyst stability, the space time (W/F) was changed to 19.5 gcatal. min/gDPE. Apparently, the DPE conversion sharply decreases from ca. 97.0% to ca. 74.5% and the cyclohexane selectivity decreases from 95.0% to 76.0%. During this conditions (ca. 10 h), Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst still keeps stability. Further decreasing the space time to 15.2 gcatal. min/gDPE and keeping 10 h, the DPE conversion changes to ca. 41.0% and the cyclohexane selectivity decreases to 66.0%. After the feed flow was switched back to 27.3 gcatal. min/gDPE at 56 h, the conversion of DPE and selectivity to cyclohexane gradually rises with increasing reaction time, and finally the conversion and the selectivity almost reach 90%. Although the conversion of DPE and the selectivity to cyclohexane over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst slight decreases after 68 h comparing with the initial data, the catalyst remains stable as expected. These results imply that Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst exhibits favorable stability. 4 Conclusions A series of strong solid acid nanosheets modified Pt/CNTs catalysts were successfully synthesized. Bifunctional Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst presents remarkable performance and high selectivity to oxygen free product cyclohexane in HDO of DPE under mild conditions, i.e. at 200 °C and 3.0 MPa, which is ascribed to the synergistic effect of uniformly dispersed Pt nanoparticles and the solid nanosheets with abundant acid sites. In addition, in the HDO of several other aromatic model compounds, including phenol, anisole, 2-phenylethyl phenyl ether and guaiacol, bifunctional Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst also exhibits high efficiency, except for the HDO of guaiacol because of the high BDEs of CO bond and probably stronger steric hindrance effect. The obvious interactions among components have a negative impact on the HDO of the lignin-derived aromatic mixture model compounds and should be investigated further. In terms of the catalyst stability test, the Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst shows favorable stability after a continuous run for 68 h at 200 °C and 3.0 MPa. All these findings indicated that strong solid acid nanosheets modified Pt/CNTs could be novel and promising catalysts for the direct HDO of actual lignin into oxygen-free hydrocarbons. coredata.dc:description: Efficient upgrading of lignin bio-oils into oxygen-free liquid alkane fuels is a challenging task owing to the incompatibility of the phenolic feedstock with conventional fuels and the availability of effective hydrotreating catalysts based on the current refinery infrastructure. In this work, a series of solid acid nanosheets (HNbWO6, HNbMoO6, HTaWO6) modified Pt/CNTs bifunctional catalysts were evaluated in hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin-derived compounds. The effects of types of nanosheets and the synergistic effect between metal sites and acid sites were discussed via HDO of diphenyl ether. Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst exhibited the most efficient performance for the HDO of diphenyl ether to cyclohexane (conversion: 99.7%, selectivity: 96.4%) at 200 °C, 3.0 MPa. Several lignin aromatic model compounds including phenol, anisole, 2-phenylethyl phenyl ether and guaiacol were also investigated over Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst. Due to the different bond-dissociation energies of CO bond and steric hindrance effect, guaiacol and phenol are more difficult to be converted than diphenyl ether and anisole based on the yield of cyclohexane. It was found that the Pt/HNbWO6/CNTs catalyst exhibited favorable stability. These results validated that it is desirable to utilize this catalyst in the HDO of actual lignin macromolecules into hydrocarbon fuels.
coredata.dc:title: Nb(Ta)-based solid acid modified Pt/CNTs catalysts for hydrodeoxygenation of lignin-derived compounds
